timeline.message: Fix for feature request #3313 in Aliasing Checker
Fix for explicit annotation check in Aliasing Checker
Adding test cases for removal of explicit annotation check
Ensuring all framework tests are passed
Fix for feature request #3313 in Aliasing Checker

Revert "Fix for feature request #3313 in Aliasing Checker"

This reverts commit fd536c4de755dc1c53adbca9ad2b684e9b39a055.

timeline.bodyText: You should try to avoid operations on strings. Is there no TypeKind to compare against?
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: Ping.
replies.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: I have used your suggested logic in my latest commit. There is no need for array TypeKind comparison in the code.
replies.author: aditya3434

timeline.bodyText: What is the motivation for this special logic? You should explain the logic here or at least in the PR description.
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: Also, do add tests that cover such special logic, in at least a few important cases.
replies.author: wmdietl
aditya3434

replies.bodyText:
Can you clarify what you mean with "user defined"?
Why should the handling of explicit annotations depend on whether the class is "user defined"?
replies.author: wmdietl
aditya3434

replies.bodyText:
We do not want different behavior for built-in classes and user-defined classes. The same logic should be applied to all source code, regardless of who wrote the code.
There is a difference between classes String and Data in these two examples.
In String the default constructor is annotated as returning a unique object. The class declaration is not annotated. Therefore, it is fine in the test case to have a non-unique String reference.
On the other hand class Data in this new test case is annotated as @Unique requiring that only @Unique references exist.
So your check should be for that difference between the two classes.
Also can you move the annotations from framework/tests/aliasing/stubfile.astub into typetools/jdk#52?
replies.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: I have added a new method for the above requested logic. Now the code doesn't need to deal with the special cases of arrays, null and java.lang classes. I have used the getDeclAnnotations method to get the set of declared annotations of the class as a whole, and then searched for the unique annotation mirror in the set. The code now gives leaked errors without explicit annotations only when the class is annotated as @unique. Annotating just the constructor will allow non-unique object references.
replies.author: aditya3434

timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: Ping.
replies.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: No, the type of the left-hand side isn't important. However, the method doesn't give an error, even when Data is explicitly annotated as @unique.
replies.author: aditya3434

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure how you mean this. Does Object z = p; not raise an error? Shouldn't it?
replies.author: wmdietl
aditya3434

replies.bodyText:
Ok, can you expand this test case with the Object local variable and the expected error.
Then file an issue that shows the problem with the return version.
replies.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: The caller already computed type and you don't seem to use exp in this method. So why not just pass the type as parameter?

replies.bodyText: I replaced exp with type as an argument in the isUniqueClass in my latest commit
replies.author: aditya3434

revised_code.chunk:
diff --git a/framework/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/common/aliasing/AliasingVisitor.java b/framework/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/common/aliasing/AliasingVisitor.java
index 95b6d6318..9a6556f68 100644
--- a/framework/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/common/aliasing/AliasingVisitor.java
+++ b/framework/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/common/aliasing/AliasingVisitor.java

@@ -257,7 +264,9 @@ public class AliasingVisitor extends BaseTypeVisitor<AliasingAnnotatedTypeFactor
 
     /**
      * Returns true if {@code exp} has type {@code @Unique} and is not a method invocation nor a new
-     * class expression.
+     * class expression. It checks whether the tree expression is unique by either checking for an
+     * explicit annotation or checking whether the class of the tree expression {@code exp} has type
+     * {@code @Unique}
      *
      * @param exp the Tree to check
      */

timeline.bodyText: It might be easier as if (el == null) { return false; } and then the same for annoMirrors.
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: I have separated out el and annoMirrors checks instead of the nested if conditions. If either of them is null, the method returns false

timeline.bodyText: Again, don't use Strings for things like this. Can you use AnnotationUtils.containsSameByClass https://github.com/typetools/checker-framework/blob/master/javacutil/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/javacutil/AnnotationUtils.java#L230 ? Then you don't need the for loop.
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: I have used the AnnotationUtils.containtsSameByClass method in my latest commit
replies.author: aditya3434
